msDesc.head: Bede, Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum, in Old English

summary.seg: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College MS 41 (hereafter CCCC MS 41) is a copy of the Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum (The Ecclesiastical History of the English People) by Bede Bede, the Venerable, Saint, 673-735 , who lived and worked at the Benedictine monastery in Jarrow in the north-east of England from the late seventh century until his death in 735. Bede composed around forty works during his lifetime, and he listed most of them in a post-script at the end of the Historia ecclesiastica, located in this manuscript on pp. 479-482. The majority of Bede's writings are guides to help readers study and understand various books of the Bible, but he also produced homilies, textbooks on grammar and the composition of poetry, books on the lives of saints and other important religious figures, and books on the natural sciences and computus.

By far his most famous work, then and now, the Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum is a history of the Christian church in England from the first conversion efforts, to the establishment of monastic sites, to the connections (and occasional conflicts) between kings and various abbesses and abbots, priests and bishops, and monks and nuns. Bede cast his research back into the distant past and tried to describe the pre-Roman peoples of Britain and their customs, life in Roman Britain, contemporary events in mainland Europe, and the migration to and settlement in what is now England by various Germanic tribes in the 5th and 6th centuries. Although there are some inaccuracies in the text, Bede was a careful and diligent researcher, and took care to inform his readers where he had found his information, his assessment of its veracity, and its potential corroboration in other sources. The Historia ecclesiastica is also full of personal detail, particularly as the narrative moves closer to Bede's own lifetime, with anecdotes about shepherds and princesses, travel and debates, and miraculous stories of healing and divine intervention.

The Historia ecclesiastica was very widely circulated, not just in England but in many parts of north-western Europe. The Latin version of the text has survived in part or in full in over 150 manuscripts, but CCCC MS 41 is one of fewer than ten surviving partial or complete copies of the Old English version of the text. Other significant copies are:
Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.3.18
London, British Library, Additional MS 43703 (1562 copy (i.e., pre-fire damage) of London, British Library, MS Cotton Otho B xi
London, British Library, Cotton Domitian A ix, f. 11 (fragment)
London, British Library, Cotton Otho B xi, ff. 1-38 (damaged by fire in 1731)
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Tanner 10
Oxford, Corpus Christi College, MS 279B

CCCC MS 41 was written in the first half of the eleventh century, probably somewhere in the south of England. The manuscript is large and has generous margins, which later that century were used to accommodate a number of other texts, ranging from the Old English Poem Solomon and Saturn, to liturgical texts, and medical recipes and charms in Old English. At least some of the marginal additions were probably made at Exeter: CCCC MS 41 was one of the manuscripts given to Exeter Cathedral by Leofric, Bishop of Exeter Leofric, Bishop of Exeter (d. 1072) who was bishop there from 1050 to 1072 - the manuscript still contains a bilingual curse for anyone who might try to remove the book from the Cathedral. The curse, on p. 488 is as follows: 'Hunc librum dat leofricus episcopus ecclesie sancti petri apostoli in exonia ubi sedes episcopalis est ad utilitatem successorum suorum. Si quis illum abstulerit inde, subiaceat maledictioni. FIAT. FIAT. FIAT. Ðas boc gef Leofric. b. into sce petres mynstre on exancestre þaer se bisceopstol is for saƿle alisednysse 7 gif hig hƿa ut æt brede god hine fordo on þære e...' (This book was given by Leofric, bishop of the church of Saint Peter the Apostle in Exeter where his episcopal seat is for the use of his successors. If anyone steals it, may they be put under a curse. Let it be so. Let it be so. Let it be so).

A list of the books donated to Exeter by Bishop Leofric survives in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Auct D.2.16 ('The Leofric Missal'), ff. 1r-2v, but this particular volume is not included in that list. Other manuscripts that were part of Leofric's gift to Exeter, and which were also once in the possession of Matthew Parker include Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.2.11 an eleventh-century copy of the Gospels in Old English, which contains a donation inscription on f. 1r: 'Hunc textum euangeliorum dedit Leofricus episcopus ecclesiae sancti petri apostoli in exonia ad utilitatem successorum suorum. Ðas boc leofric bisceop gef sancto petro 7 eallum his æftergengum in to exancestre gode mid to ðenienne' (Bishop Leofric of the church of Saint Peter the Apostle in Exeter gave this book of the gospels for the use of his successors). Another is Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.2.4 , an eleventh-century copy of Gregory the Great's Cura pastoralis in the Old English translation attributed to King Alfred.

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Late-19th or early-20th century pagination (paper endleaves foliated).

Pagination in pencil in the upper outer corner of each recto from 25 onward. The pencil-paginator corrects the ink-paginator's many mistakes throughout the volume and where a leaf has both an ink and a pencil page number, the number in pencil should be used. It should be noted that the page designations in pencil are significantly fainter than those in ink, particularly when working with the digitised surrogate.
The final parchment endleaf is paginated as pp. 489-490, perhaps in error, as its counterpart is foliated as f. i at the beginning of the volume.
Note that the paper endleaves [a]-[b] and [c]-[d] and the first parchment endleaf (f. i), are foliated rather than paginated.
Pagination in ink in the upper outer corner of each recto. This pagination sequence contains significant errors and should not be used.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 31 quires, most comprising 8 leaves, but with minor variations in form in several places. The fourth leaf was cancelled from Quire 13, and the sixth leaf from Quire 31, with no interruption to the main text. Two quires are not solely comprised of nested bifolia; the fourth and fifth leaves in Quire 9, and the third and sixth leaves in Quire 16 are singletons arranged into two sets of paired half-sheets that take the place of a bifolium in each quire.

The manuscript was completed in two possibly simultaneous copying stints, the first from pp. 1-206 (Quires 1-13), and the second from pp. 488 onwards (Quires 14-31); evidence for the stints can be seen in the two sequences of quire designations used in this volume, the first of which encompasses Quires 1-13 and the second of which encompasses Quires 14-30 (Quire 31 lacks its final leaf). In addition, the mise-en-page of p. 206 reflects scribal awareness of an approaching link with another portion of the text; the text on p. 206 is much more widely spaced than earlier in the volume, and the text ends abruptly, mid-sentence, not at the end of a line, and leaving a much larger lower margin than is typical even by the expansive marginal standards common to this volume.

The manuscript has been rebound since it was examined by M.R. James for his 1912 Catalogue, and so his description of the binding and the endleaves is no longer an accurate reflection of the physical characteristics of the volume. The endleaves in the current binding are arranged as follows: two paper leaves coterminous with the current a binding (ff. [a]-[b], a c. 16th century parchment endleaf (f. i), the core 11th century leaves (pp. 1-488), a c. 16th century parchment endleaf (pp. 489-490), and two paper endleaves (ff. [c]-[d]. The parchment endleaf at the beginning of the manuscript is foliated and has the Roman numeral designation 'i', but the parchment endleaf at the end of the manuscript was included within the main Hindu-Arabic pagination sequence and has the designation 'pp. 489-490'.

list.item: 2 modern paper endleaves (foliated as ff. a - b) +
2 modern paper endleaves (ff. c recto - d verso)

p.formula: 18 26 3-88 96+2 (4th and 5th singletons) 10-128 1310-1 (4th cancelled) 14-158 166+2 (3rd and 6th singletons) 17-308 316-1 (6th excised) + pp. 488-489 + c-d

signatures.p: Alphabetical quire signatures present in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire of pp. 1-488. There are two sequences of alphabetical quire signatures in the volume, the first begins on p. 92 the final verso of Quire 6 with the designation 'F' and this sequence continues to 'M' on p. 188 the final verso of Quire 12. As there are no gaps in the text in Quires 1-5, it is likely that they once bore the designations 'A'-'E' and that their sigla have subsequently been trimmed away. A second quire signature sequence begins at Quire 14, with Quire 13's final verso, p. 222 designated as 'A' and this sequence continuing in medieval alphabetical order (i.e., with 'I' and without 'J') to the designation 'R' on p. 478 on the final verso of Quire 30.

supportDesc.condition: Outer margins trimmed away from pp. 315-318.

note.p: Note in pencil on f. a recto: 'Ultra-violet yields no more information on p. 1.' The note is signed R.I.P (for Raymond Ian Page), former Fellow Librarian of the Parker Library and dated 7 February 1981.

binding.p: Rebound on 15 April 1953. A note recording the rebinding is present on f. a recto: 'MS. 41 Rebound by John P. Gray of 10, Green St. (Pilgrim Trust grant) 15.iv.53. . J. P. T. B.' (i.e. John Patrick Tuer Bury (1908-1987), historian and fellow of Corpus Christi College).

Fully bound in light brown leather over mill-board. The leather covering the boards is undecorated except for decoration applied to the raised bands on the spine which extends across the joints and onto the front and back covers. Five raised bands on spine, each decorated with a blind single-fillet along the upper and lower perimeters of the band; the fillets extend in pairs across the joints and onto the front and back covers and taper into a decorative point. The upper and lower openings of the spine are each decorated with a blind single-fillet across the width of the spine and inset from the opening by c. 10 mm. Three compartments on the spine bear text tooled in gold, 'M S .' '41' and 'CCCC' respectively. The spine is capped at head and tail and no bands are visible. Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins, both blank.

The present leaves f. i and pp. 489-490 are both former pastedowns and contain text in a hand of the 16th century; both leaves are coated in an adhesive residue on their outermost sides, and have wear in a pattern indicating their proximity to the former binding's turn ins.

Neil Ker states that the binding replaced by J.P. Gray in April 1953 was 'of s. xviii'; this is the binding that M.R. James would have seen when he examined CCCC MS 41 for his Catalogue. The endleaves were probably added to the volume in a 16th-century binding, given the re-use of similar such documents in other manuscripts once in the possession of Matthew Parker. N. Ker, Catalogue of Manuscripts Containing Anglo-Saxon (Oxford, 2nd edn., 1990), no. 32

provenance.p: All Parts (i.e., f. i, and pp. 1-488, 489-490) together by the end of the 18th century, and perhaps before that.

acquisition.p: Pages 1-488 given to Corpus Christi College in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. Annotations in the characteristic orange-red crayon used by Parker and his circle throughout the volume. It is possible that f. i and pp. 489-490 were already bound with pp. 1-488 at the time of Parker's gift to Corpus Christi College.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the existing online catalogue record for available at CCCC 41 as well as Neil Ker's description of the manuscript [no. 32] in his Catalogue of Manuscripts Containing Anglo-Saxon.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

listBibl.bibl: For a bibliography for this item maintained by Corpus Christi College Cambridge see: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 41: Zotero Bibliography

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College MS 41, f. i and pp. 489-490
msIdentifier.msName: Part 1 - 16th century documents - former pastedowns (first section)

note.p: Two leaves (f. i and pp. 489-490), one at each end of the earlier medieval textblock. Both leaves are former pastedowns, and have since been lifted. The leaves bear traces of adhesive residue and have been trimmed for reuse as binding waste, and as such, the text is illegible in some places and incomplete in others.

Legal document written in a 16th century hand. The legal text is only present on one side of each leaf, i.e., f. i recto, and p. 490. The text refers to places in and around Cambridge including a 'Thomas Hobbeson in ecclesia parochiali sancti Clementis Cantabrigi' (Thomas Hobbeson in the ecclesiastical parish of St Clement's Cambridge); St Clement's church is on Bridge Street in Cambridge. This part of the document may contain a reference to the Thomas Hobson (c. 1544-1630) Hobson, Thomas, approximately 1544-1630 , citizen of Cambridge, haulier, stablemaster, and businessman. One difficulty with associating this note with him is that he moved to Cambridge in 1568 and lived on Trumpington Street, making him a parishoner of St Bene't's, where he is also buried.
Other names visible in the document are 'Robert Stewkyn', and 'magistri Edwardi Heynes Notarii publicii'. There is also a reference to the village of Fenstanton.

msItem.title: Notes in the hand of Abraham Wheelocke comparing this manuscript to Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.3.18
msItem.author: Abraham Wheelocke
msItem.note: Cambridge, University Library, MS Kk.3.18 was used by Wheelocke as the basis for his edition of the Old English Historia ecclesiastica.

listBibl.bibl: See M. Budny, R. I. Page, and D. M. Wilson, Insular, Anglo-Saxon, and Early Anglo-Norman Manuscript Art at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge: An Illustrated Catalogue, 2 vols (Kalamazoo, Mich., 1997), pp. 501-524, esp. p. 512

collation.p: Two leaves, perhaps once part of the same original document sheet, but now separate and used as pastedowns for a former Corpus Christi MS 41 binding.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Both f. i and pp. 489-490 were once pastedowns in a former Corpus Christi MS 41 binding. Both f. i and pp. 489-490 may once have been part of the same single-sheet document, or they may have always been distinct leaves, but there is too much damage to determine their original relationship except to note that they derive from the same source item. There is adhesive residue on f. i recto and p. 490 - both leaves were pastedowns in a former binding and have since been lifted, making both sides of each leaf accessible, but the adhesive residue has obscured much of the text on both leaves. Both leaves have been trimmed from their original size, with loss of text around all perimeters of the leaves due to trimming.

layout.p: Original layout undertermined due to extensive trimming.

handNote.p: Written in a secretary minuscule with occasional enlarged names and section headers.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

binding.p: The leaves f. i and pp. 489-490 were used as pastedowns in a former binding as both f. i recto and p. 490 are coated in an adhesive residue. The binding probably included wood boards and metal clasps across the fore edge as f. i and pp. 489-490 have worm damage and abrasions characteristic of pastedowns over wood boards, and both have metallic staining in typical positions for for fore edge fastenings.

origin.origPlace: England, probably in or near Cambridge.
origin.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features. Place of production assigned based on two references to places in or near Cambridge, England.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 41, pp. 1-488
msIdentifier.msName: Part 2 - The Old English translation of Bede's Ecclesiastical History and various shorter texts in Old English

msContents.textLang: Old English with occasional phrases and short texts in Latin

msItem.title: Historia ecclesiastica Gentis Anglorum in Old English
msItem.author: Bede
msItem.textLang: Old English with occasional Latin phrases
msItem.incipit: 1 Ðis is seo gesettnes ðisse brytenne oð hibernia scotta ealandes on heora Ðam ærran begangam
msItem.explicit: 484 þæt he on riht mote oð his daga ende drihten herigan AMEN

list.item: Preface, including Bede's address to his readers and his letter to Ceolwulf - pp. 18-22

msItem.note: Note that the text of the Old English Historia Ecclesiastica in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 41 closes with a metrical colophon on pp. 483-484 found only in this manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: Edition of the text: J. Schipper, König Alfreds Übersetzung Von Bedas Kirchengeschichte, Bibliothek Der Angelsächsischen Prosa 4 (Leipzig 1897-1899), 2 vols. Edited as manuscript 'B'.

Discussed as manuscript 'B' in a study of the manuscripts of the Old English Historia Ecclesiastica in Sharon Rowley, The Old English Version of Bede's 'Historia Ecclesiastica' (Boydell & Brewer, 2011)

bletsung to candelun

msItem.incipit: 2 Domine Iesu Christe creator celi

msItem.explicit: 47Cummunicantes et noctem

msItem.explicit: 60 ut quorum sollemnia caelebramus eorum orationibus adiuuemur . per dominum
msItem.note: Written in the upper and outer margin.

msItem.title: Mass for the Discovery of the Cross

msItem.explicit: 60 pro salute mundi triumphare iussisti . per dominum nostrum ihesum christum filium tuum.
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.explicit: 71 leuate caputa nostra
msItem.note: Written in the upper margins.

msItem.incipit: 74 Deus qui tribus pueris mitigasti . flammas ignium
msItem.explicit: 74 remedium esse facias et futurum per .
msItem.note: Written in the upper margin.

msItem.explicit: 75 R diligebat . U In crucem denique
msItem.note: Written in the upper and outer margin.

msItem.title: On Christmas Day and the marvels accompanying the Nativity
msItem.incipit: 122 On þone forman deeig on geare þæt is on þone ærestan geohel dæig
msItem.explicit: 124 þurh ðæt manige untrume men þær on ƿurdon gehælede
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On Saint Anastasia
msItem.incipit: 124 On þone ilcan dæig cristes acennednesse godes circean arƿorðiað sanctam anastasiam
msItem.explicit: 125 andƿearde lif ond hire lichama resteð nu on rome birig
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On Saint Euphemia
msItem.incipit: 125 On ðone forman dæig bið sancta eufemian tid
msItem.explicit: 128 ond hire lichama resteð ƿið rome birig an þam ƿege þema nemneð LATINA
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On Saint Stephen
msItem.incipit: 128 On þone æfteran dæig godes circean arƿorðiað Sanctus Stephanus
msItem.explicit: 130 þa heo eft com þa mitte heo hire cild lifiende ond gesund
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On Saint John the Evangelist
msItem.incipit: 130 On þone .iii. dæig bið sancte iohannes tid þæs godspellres
msItem.explicit: 131 forþam nat nænig man hƿæþer se iohannes si þe cƿicu þe dead
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On the Massacre of the Innocents
msItem.incipit: 131 On þone feorðan dæig þið þara haligra cilda
msItem.explicit: 132 ond he ofstang hine silfne mid his agenre handa
msItem.note: Written in the outer and lower margin.

msItem.title: On Saint Sylvester
msItem.incipit: 132 On þone .vii. dæg þæs monþes bið sancte silvestres
msItem.explicit: 132 þa cƿæt sanctus silluester to him disega on þisse nihte þe bið þæt fearh afirred . ond þæt gelamp
msItem.note: Written in the outer margin.

msItem.title: Offices for Advent
msItem.incipit: 134 ut redemptionis nostrae sollemnitas et praesentis
msItem.explicit: 139 et praesens nobis remedium esse facias et futurum . per
msItem.note: Written in the upper and outer margins.

msItem.title: Liturgy of the Mass
msItem.rubric: 158 MISSA QUAM SACERDOS PRO SE DEBET
msItem.incipit: 158 Suppliciter te deus pater omnipotens qui es creator
msItem.explicit: 158 et in specie uulnerati medicus ambulauit . hic nobis dominus
msItem.note: Upper and outer margin.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: 182 Pietatem tuam quesumus domine nostrorum absolue uincula delictorum
msItem.explicit: 182 et defunctorum peccata dimitte eiusque premia eterne concede . per .
msItem.note: Written in the outer margin.

msItem.title: Medical Recipe - ƿið ymbe
msItem.note: Full transcription: ƿið ymbe nim eorþan oferƿeorp mid þinre sƿiþran handa under þinum sƿiþran fet ond cƿet foic under fot funde ic hit hƿæt eorðe mæg ƿið ealra ƿihta gehƿilce ond ƿið andan ond wið æminde ond ƿið þa micelan mannes tungan ond ƿið on for ƿeorp ofer greot þonne hi sƿirman ond cƿeð sitte ge sige ƿif sigað to eorþan næfre ge ƿilde tu ƿuda fleogan beo ge swa gemindige mines godes sƿa bið manna gehƿilc metes ond eþeles.
Written in the outer margin.

msItem.explicit: 194 et omnium simul sanctorum uirginumque salutem mentis et corporis . et ad perpetuam peruenire gloriam . per .
msItem.note: Written in the upper and outer margins.

msItem.title: Salomon and Saturn (incomplete)
msItem.incipit: 196 Saturnus cƿæð hƿæt Ic iglanda eallra hæbbe boca onbyrged þurh gebregdstafas
msItem.explicit: 198 A ofermægene 7 hine eac ofslehð .T.
msItem.note: Written in the upper, outer, and lower margin.
The only other known version of the poem is in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 422 ('The Red Book of Darley').

msItem.title: Charms for the Protection of Cattle

msItem.note: Full transcription: Ne for stolen ne for holen nan uht þæs ðe Ic age þe ma ðe mihte herod urne drihten Ic geþohte sancte ead elenan ond ic geþohte crist on rode ahangen swa ic þence þis feoh to findanne næs to oðfeorrganne ond to ƿitanne næs to oðƿyrceanne, and to lufianne næs to oðlædanne gar mund godes ðegen find þæt feoh . ond fere þæt feoh ond hafa þæt feoh and heald þæt feoh ond fere ham þæt feoh þæt he næfre næbbe landes þæt he hit oðlæde ne foldan þæt hit oðferie ne husa þæt he hit oð hit healde Gif hyt hwa gedo ne gedige hit him næfre binnan þrym nihtum cunne ic his mihta his mægen ond his mihta ond his mundcræftas eall he weornige swa syer ƿudu ƿeornie sƿa breðel þeo sƿa þystel se ðe ðis feoh oðfergean þence oððe ðis orf oðehtian ðence amen.
Written in the lower margin.

listBibl.bibl: Cockayne, Leechdoms I, pp. 384-385

msItem.explicit: 206 sƿa næfre ðeos dæd forholen ne ƿyrþe . per crucem Christi
msItem.note: Written in the lower margin.

msItem.title: Prayer against the ferocity of enemies
msItem.textLang: Latin with title in Old English
msItem.incipit: 272 Dextera domini fecit uirtutem, dextera domini exaltauit me
msItem.explicit: 272 deus in unitate spiritus sancti per omnia secula seculorum
msItem.note: Written in the outer margin.

This text is found in the midst of the Homily copied in the margins of pp. 254-280. The homily resumes a line and a half after the prayer ends, and it is possible that the prayer was copied first, and that the scribe of the homily had to work around the pre-existing prayer when adding the homily to the margins of CCCC MS 41.

'Dextera domini ...' is Psalm 117:16-17 and is also found in a charm against fevers ('Contra febres') in Durham, Cathedral Library, MS Hunter 100, f. 117r where the reader is directed to copy an abbreviated form of the charm onto an iron crucifix to be worn by the patient.

msItem.title: Three medical prayers
msItem.textLang: Latin with titles in Old English

msItem.title: Medicinal prayer for sore eyes
msItem.note: Full transcription: Ƿið sarum eagum Domine sancte pater omnipotens æterne deus sana occulos hominis istius .N. sicut sanasti occulus filii tobi et multorum cecorum manus aridorum pes claudorum sanitas egrorum resurrectio mortuorum felicitas martirum et omnium sanctorum oro domine ut erigas et inluminas occulos famuli tui .N. in quacunque ualitudine constraitum medellis celestibus sanare digneris tribue famulo tuo .N. ut armis iustitie munitur diabolo resistat et regnum consequamtur æternum . per .

msItem.title: Medicinal prayer for sore ears
msItem.note: Full transcription: Ƿið sarum earum Rex glorie christe raphaelem angelum exclude fandoraohel auribus famulo dei .illi. mox recede ab aurium torquenti sed in raphaelo angelo sanitatem auditui componas . per

msItem.title: Medicinal prayer for sickness

msItem.title: Homily with narrative of The Passion
msItem.incipit: 484 MEN ÞA LEOFSTAN ðe gehirað nu hu drihten ƿæs sprecende on þas tid to his geferum
msItem.explicit: 488 fon cundan hirusalem þam drihtene sie ƿuldor ond ƿeorðmind . In ealra ƿoruld a woruld abutan ende AMEN fiat

listBibl.bibl: Edited in J.S. Grant, Three Homilies from Cambridge, Corpus Christi College 41: The Assumption, St Michael and the Passion (Ottawa, 1982), pp. 78-110
Cameron B3.2.19

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.

Alphabetical quire signatures present in the lower margin of the last verso of most quires. There are two sequences of alphabetical quire signatures in the volume, the first partially incomplete due to trimming, and the second apparently complete. The first remaining designation in the first sequence is the designation 'F' on p. 92 (the final verso of Quire 6); this sequence continues to 'M' on p. 188 the final verso of Quire 12. As there are no textual gaps in Quires 1-5, these quires presumably once bore the designations 'A'-'E' before the sigla were lost to trimming. A second quire signature sequence begins at Quire 14; p. 206 (the final verso of Quire 14) has the designation 'A' and the sequence continues to the designation 'R' on p. 478, the final leaf of Quire 30. Since the second sequence begins with an 'A' at the end of Quire 14, Quire 13 was perhaps included in the first medieval collation sequence for the volume, and so may have lost an 'N' designation to trimming.

supportDesc.condition: In good condition. Substantial portions of outer margins trimmed away from pp. 315-318.

layout.seg: Ruled in drypoint, frame and line in single-column format. 23-28 written lines to the page from pp. 1-484, written above top line. Marginal space is substantial and the margins have been used to record a variety of additional texts, each employing an idiosyncratic text layout.
Ruled in drypoint, frame and line in single-column format. 41-42 written lines to the page from pp. 484-488, written above top line.

handNote.p: The main text written in English vernacular minuscule by two main scribes. Scribe 1 worked from pp. 1-190 line 20, and Scribe 2 from pp. 190-488 replacing Scribe 1 at line 21 on p. 190. Where Latin is copied by the main scribes it is written in the same script as was used for the Old English; this is contrary to typical practice in 11th century England, where scribes would typically use an English vernacular minuscule for Old English, and an Anglo-Caroline minuscule for Latin.

listBibl.bibl: P. Stokes, English Vernacular Minuscule from Æthelred to Cnut, c. 990 – c. 1035, Publications of the Manchester Centre for Anglo-Saxon Studies 14 (Cambridge, 2014)

handNote.p: The mise-en-page of the manuscript resulted in generous margins, which were subsequently filled with related and unrelated texts by several further scribes who all added their texts in English vernacular minuscule, with varying levels of influence from the English form of Caroline minuscule that was used for copying Latin texts in England in the eleventh-century.

listBibl.bibl: P. Stokes, English Vernacular Minuscule from Æthelred to Cnut, c. 990 – c. 1035, Publications of the Manchester Centre for Anglo-Saxon Studies 14 (Cambridge, 2014)

handNote.p: On p. 488 there is a donation inscription in Latin and Old English recording the gift of the manuscript from Bishop Leofric to the religious community at Exeter Cathedral, his episcopal seat. The Latin portion of the inscription is in a later-eleventh century Anglo-Caroline minuscule, and is in a hand of similar appearance to the hand that copied the Old English version of the donation inscription directly below the Latin text. The donation inscription has been dated to 1069x1072, and the position of the inscription on the page suggests that it can be used as a terminus ante quem for the rest of the manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: P. Stokes, English Vernacular Minuscule from Æthelred to Cnut, c. 990 - c. 1035, Publications of the Manchester Centre for Anglo-Saxon Studies 14 (Cambridge, 2014), esp. p. 41
D.A.E. Pelteret, Catalogue of English Post-Conquest Vernacular Documents (Woodbridge, 1990), esp. pp. 98-9 (no. 92)
Elaine M. Drage, 'Bishop Leofric and the Exeter Cathedral Chapter, 1050-1072: A Reassessment of the Manuscript Evidence' (unpublished D.Phil. dissertation, University of Oxford, 1978), pp. 29-41

handNote.p: On p. 488 there is a donation inscription in Latin and Old English recording the gift of the manuscript from Bishop Leofric to the religious community at Exeter Cathedral, his episcopal seat. The Old English portion of the inscription is in a later-eleventh century English Vernacular minuscule, and is in a hand of similar appearance to the hand that copied the Latin version of the donation inscription directly above the Old English text. The donation inscription has been dated to 1069x1072, and the position of the inscription on the page suggests that it can be used as a terminus ante quem for the rest of the manuscript.

listBibl.bibl: P. Stokes, English Vernacular Minuscule from Æthelred to Cnut, c. 990 - c. 1035, Publications of the Manchester Centre for Anglo-Saxon Studies 14 (Cambridge, 2014), esp. p. 41
D. A. E. Pelteret, Catalogue of English Post-Conquest Vernacular Documents (Woodbridge, 1990), esp. pp. 98-9 (no. 92)
Elaine M. Drage, 'Bishop Leofric and the Exeter Cathedral Chapter, 1050-1072: A Reassessment of the Manuscript Evidence' (unpublished D.Phil. dissertation, University of Oxford, 1978), pp. 29-41

decoNote.p: Incomplete drawing of Christ, crucified, outline only, in brown ink on p. 484. On the opposite page, p. 485 an incomplete figure of a ?nude? onlooker standing on a small hill or mound looks over towards Christ. Both illustrations are palimpsest, overwritten with a homily on the Passion Men ðe gehirað nu hu ....

Decorative initials combining zoomorphic, gymnastic, and inhabited details, typically rendered in light brown ink, sometimes with a red outline wash. The largest decorative initial is on p. 1, with other smaller initials on pp. 61, 206, 224, 224, 230, 233, 246, 248, 251, 252, 253, 254, 259, 261, 264, 266, 268, 272, 273, 276, 282, 285, 289, 292, 300, 301, 307, 352, 394, 400, 410, 433.

Simple decorative initials in dark brown ink, typically an enlarged majuscule with an emphasis on the contrast between thick and thin strokes, sometimes incorporating monogram and cipher techniques to include several letters within one matrix.

There are a large number of unfilled spaces reserved for decorative initials throughout the volume at book and chapter division, and in particular in the leaves copied by Scribe 1, i.e., pp. 1-190. The only zoomorphic, gymnastic or interlaced initals accompanying Scribe 1's stint can be found on, pp. 1 and 61.

Rubrication and display scripts more common in the opening leaves of the volume. The first page of the text p. 1 opens with a large zoomorphic Ð, followed by several words written in decorative majuscules loosely inspired by Square Capitals, and then further lines in Rustic Captials, and these two registers are used for rubrication (sometimes also washed with a red pigment) throughout the volume.

note.p: Catalogue number 'S.2' in dark brown ink in the outer margin of p. 1 indicating the designation of this item in William Stanley's Catalogue of the manuscripts of Corpus Christi College published in 1722.
A title for the volume in an early modern hand in dark ink in the upper margin of p. 1: 'Histor Bede Collegij Corp. Christi Cantabr. Sum incola'.

The number 'xxiiii' in red ink in an early medieval style on p. 1; the number is by the upper part of the bow of the large decorative Ð on that leaf and is significantly blurred and blackened due to oxidation.
An informal 'aue' in brown ink in the upper margin of p. 1.
The number '117' in faded brown ink in the upper inner corner of p. 1.
The name ælf in faint brown ink in an 11th-century hand (p. 155).
The name ælfƿine in dark brown ink in an 11th-century hand (p. 155).
The name ælfƿerd in brown ink in an 11th-century hand (p. 242, outer margin).
Modern quire numbering in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire in a 20th-century hand.

origin.origDate: 11th century, probably c. 1000-1050, and by 1072 at the latest.
origin.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features. The terminus ante quem for the main text is the Leofrician donation inscription on p. 488, which must have been added to the volume before 1072 as Leofric died in that year; in all likelihood, the text of the Old English Historia Ecclesiastica in this manuscript was completed in the first half of the eleventh century.
Place of production assigned based on palaeographical and linguistic features. For a discussion of the possibility of a Crediton origin for the volume, see Stokes (2014).

listBibl.bibl: P. Stokes, English Vernacular Minuscule from Æthelred to Cnut, c. 990 - c. 1035, Publications of the Manchester Centre for Anglo-Saxon Studies 14 (Cambridge, 2014), esp. p. 41
D.A.E. Pelteret, Catalogue of English Post-Conquest Vernacular Documents (Woodbridge, 1990), esp. pp. 98-9 (no. 92)
Elaine M. Drage, 'Bishop Leofric and the Exeter Cathedral Chapter, 1050-1072: A Reassessment of the Manuscript Evidence' (unpublished D.Phil. dissertation, University of Oxford, 1978), pp. 29-41

provenance.p: Donation inscription on p. 488: 'Hunc librum dat leofricus episcopus ecclesie sancti petri apostoli in exonia ubi sedes episcopalis est ad utilitatem successorum suorum. Si quis illum abstulerit inde, subiaceat maledictioni. FIAT. FIAT. FIAT. Ðas boc gef Leofric. b. into sce petres mynstre on exancestre þaer se bisceopstol is for (his) saƿle alisednysse 7 gif hig hƿa ut æt brede god hine fordo on þære e...' (This book was given by Leofric, bishop of the church of Saint Peter the Apostle in Exeter where his episcopal seat is for the use of his successors. If anyone steals it, may they be put under a curse. Let it be so. Let it be so. Let it be so) .

Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 41 was one of the manuscripts given to Exeter Cathedral by Leofric, bishop of Exeter (d. 1072) Leofric, Bishop of Exeter, -1072 , who was bishop there from 1050 to 1072, and it still contains a bilingual donation inscription cursing anyone who might try to remove the book from the Cathedral. Before being appointed Bishop of Exeter in c. 1050, Leofric was appointed Bishop of Cornwall and Bishop of Crediton by King Edward the Confessor. Leofric requested and received papal permission to move the episcopal seat to Exeter in 1050, and donated several manuscripts to Exeter upon his appointment there, so it is possible that this book and others in that donation might originate from Crediton, but this is far from certain.

acquisition.p: Pages 1-488 given to Corpus Christi College in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury. Annotations in the characteristic orange-red crayon used by Parker and his circle throughout the volume. It is possible that f. i and pp. 489-490 were already bound with pp. 1-488 at the time of Parker's gift to Corpus Christi College.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College MS 41, f. i and pp. 489-490
msIdentifier.msName: Part 1 - 16th century documents - former pastedowns (second section)

msItem.title: Note about the homily on St Michael in the hand of Abraham Wheelocke
msItem.author: Abraham Wheelocke

note.p: Full transcription: 'Angelis S. Micaelam inuocat . Saxoni margine . p . 541 .'
Refers to the homily on St Michael recorded in the margins of pp. 402-417 which are pp. 522-541 in the older, incorrect ink foliation.

listBibl.bibl: See M. Budny, R. I. Page, and D. M. Wilson, Insular, Anglo-Saxon, and Early Anglo-Norman Manuscript Art at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge: An Illustrated Catalogue, 2 vols (Kalamazoo, Mich., 1997), pp. 501-524, esp. p. 513

note.p: Two leaves (f. i and pp. 489-490), one at each end of the earlier medieval textblock. Both leaves are former pastedowns, and have since been lifted. The leaves bear traces of adhesive residue and have been trimmed for reuse as binding waste, and as such, the text is illegible in some places and incomplete in others.

Legal document written in a 16th century hand. The legal text is only present on one side of each leaf, i.e., f. i recto, and p. 490. The text refers to places in and around Cambridge including a 'Thomas Hobbeson in ecclesia parochiali sancti Clementis Cantabrigi' (Thomas Hobbeson in the ecclesiastical parish of St Clement's Cambridge); St Clement's church is on Bridge Street in Cambridge. This part of the document may contain a reference to the Thomas Hobson (c. 1544-1630) Hobson, Thomas, approximately 1544-1630 , citizen of Cambridge, haulier, stablemaster, and businessman. One difficulty with associating this note with him is that he moved to Cambridge in 1568 and lived on Trumpington Street, making him a parishoner of St Bene't's, where he is also buried.
Other names visible in the document are 'Robert Stewkyn', and 'magistri Edwardi Heynes Notarii publicii'. There is also a reference to the village of Fenstanton.

collation.p: Two leaves, perhaps once part of the same original document sheet, but now separate and used as pastedowns for a former Corpus Christi MS 41 binding.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Both f. i and pp. 489-490 were once pastedowns in a former Corpus Christi MS 41 binding. Both f. i and pp. 489-490 may once have been part of the same single-sheet document, or they may have always been distinct leaves, but there is too much damage to determine their original relationship except to note that they derive from the same source item. There is adhesive residue on f. i recto and p. 490 - both leaves were pastedowns in a former binding and have since been lifted, making both sides of each leaf accessible, but the adhesive residue has obscured much of the text on both leaves. Both leaves have been trimmed from their original size, with loss of text around all perimeters of the leaves due to trimming.

layout.p: Original layout undertermined due to extensive trimming.

handNote.p: Written in a secretary minuscule with occasional enlarged names and section headers.

decoNote.p: No significant decoration in this Part.

binding.p: The leaves f. i and pp. 489-490 were used as pastedowns in a former binding as both f. i recto and p. 490 are coated in an adhesive residue. The binding probably included wood boards and metal clasps across the fore edge as f. i and pp. 489-490 have worm damage and abrasions characteristic of pastedowns over wood boards, and both have metallic staining in typical positions for for fore edge fastenings.

origin.origPlace: England, probably in or near Cambridge.
origin.p: Date of production assigned based on palaeographical features. Place of production assigned based on two references to places in or near Cambridge, England.

item.term: Monastic and religious life--Early works to 1800

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project, Cambridge University Library
